title-group.article-title: Analysis of the tension course of polyester monofilaments characterized by a variable cross-section field

author-notes.corresp: Izabella Krucińska, Technical University of Łódź, Żeromskiego 116, Łódź 90-924, Poland Email: izabella.krucinska@p.lodz.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Analysis of the literature indicates that there is no method to forecast the course of the stress-strain curve of monofilaments characterized by variable cross-section fields. Knowledge of the tension course is crucial for predicting the durability of monofilaments often used in technical applications. Therefore, it was decided to conduct a study to show that it is feasible to describe the course of tensioning irregular polyester monofilaments on the basis of a modified rheological link model and the theory of the monofilament internal irregularity effect on elongation. A comparison of both the theoretical and experimental curves indicates that the proposed rheological model allowed us to calculate the theoretical curve, and to reliably anticipate the behaviour of irregular monofilaments during tension. In all the tested cases, the coefficient of curvilinear correlation exceeded 0.95, and it was higher than 0.99 for the majority of the analysed curves.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Linear textile products are complex objects that are characterized by a great irregularity of the material structure and a morphological irregularity that, in the case of monofilaments, is revealed in the form of a variable cross-section field. In order to describe the strength properties of linear textile products, various rheological models have been used.1–22 The most complementarymodel was proposed by Hoffman,8 where Zener's model is combined with Bingham's element. Zener's model is responsible for visco-elastic strains, while Bingham's element represents plastic strains. In further investigations, this model was modified by replacing Newton's dumper in Bingham's element with Eyring's dumper.17 Thus, successive elements with non-linear characteristics have been introduced and as a result anon-linear differential equation with no analytical solution was obtained. It seems that the lack of a complementary description of the rheological properties of linear textile products resulted from the fact that no inertial member was taken into account. Therefore Żurek and Aksan12,13 introduced an inertial element into their rheological model in order to describe the strength characteristics of rayon. This model was modified in further studies to characterize the phenomenon of relaxation and creep.22–25

Considerably less attention in the literature has been dedicated to analysing the effect of sample length on the course of a stress-strain curve. Tippet26 and Peirce27 created the theory of the weakest link in order to describe the breaking force of a sample consisting of n links, on the basis of the average value and standard deviation of the link-breaking force. The theory of theweakest link does not take into account any sample thickness irregularity, assuming that the break is due to defects in the internal structure of the linear textile product. However, further development of the weakest link theory has been directed to the analysis of how thickness irregularity of particular links influences the course of the stress-strain curve and to the assessment of rheological properties of linear textile products. An attempt was undertaken to unite the sample thickness irregularity with deformability.28–31

In this theory, the function of the strain-stress dependence was described with the n-degree multinomial and linear dependence. The theory of sample thickness irregularity with an adequate rheological model was used for the first time to describe the stress-strain curve of monofilaments in the study by Żurek, Chrzanowski and Krucinska.31

sec.title: Aim and range of study
sec.p:
From the presented literature review, it follows that there is no method for forecasting the course of stress-strain curves obtained for monofilaments characterizedby variable cross-section fields. It seems that the discussed feature strongly affects the durability of monofilaments. Therefore, we decided to continue these studies to show that it is feasible to describe the course of tensioning irregular polyester monofilaments based on the modified link rheological model and the theory of the internal irregularity of the monofilament. According to the consideration presented by Żurek et al,24 it was assumed that the modified rheological model consists of two parallel parts:
I – Hooke's spring with specific rigidity C1,
II – Hooke's spring with specific rigidity C2, connected in series with a frictional element with a constant resistance, T2, and a piston with a weight m that displaces a liquid with a specific viscosity η2.

The use of springs with specific rigidities C1 and C2 inthe initial phase reflects the linear-elastic behaviour of the object under testing. Once the critical value of the tensile stress is exceeded, a further part of the model connected with the inertial-frictional element is actuated. This system reflects visco-elastic strains through the use of a Newton dumper in the arrangement with springs C1 and C2, and the plastic strains realised through Saint-Venant's element. The parallel connection of the dumper and Saint-Venant's element, and the mass allow an approximate reflection of the phenomena described in the work by Eyring, in which a dumper with non-linear characteristics was used. The moving mass is used to interpret the macromolecular element acceleration phenomenon during tensioning after passing the frictional barrier. After deriving the rheological equation of state for the link, which in this case is considered to be a monofilament element with an identical cross-section field, a rheological equation of state for irregular monofilament was derived, assuming a specified linear density distribution along the section tested. The accomplishment of work was started from the theoretical part, in which the rheological equation ofstate for the accepted model was derived for regular andirregular samples. An analytical method was developed to determine the model coefficients, and then an algorithm is presented to verify the proposed model with the use of the numerical method. Verification was carried out for the series of results illustrating the stress-strain curve of polyester monofilaments obtained for variable experimental conditions.

sec.title: Algebraic solution of the rheological model for samples with an irregular linear density distribution along the length
sec.p:
The model illustrating the rheological properties of a polyester monofilament link is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Modified rheological model.24
For the presented model, the relationship between stress, σ, and elongation, x, in monotonic tension, can be expressed by the following equation: (1)
This equation is true when: (2) where C1 and C2 are the elasticity moduli of parallel elements of the model, and T2 is the limiting impeding stress that occurs in Saint-Venant's frictional element.
Denoting the ratio of limiting elongation, which results in plastic strain if it is exceeded, with x0, the following expression was obtained: (3)

When the internal elongation, growing at a constant rate, u, exceeds this value, a non-linear relationship will appear between stress and elongation, which can be expressed in the following form: (4) where t is the tension time of the element, and x22 describes the relationship between time and the material properties. This function is connected with the strain of the viscous element whose strain can be calculated from the rheological model. The function x22 was derived, and dependant on values taken for Δ, it can be expressed with the following equations:24 (5) (6) (7) (8) where

In order to calculate the force in the model, the values obtained from equations 6–8 should be substituted into equation 4 to obtain the following relationships:
(9)
(10) (11)

The coefficients of these equations are the constants of the object material tested, and they can be determined from independent tests, where t0 is the time within which the limiting linear elasticity is obtained during sample drawing at a constant rate,u. The physical value can be described with the equation: (12)
Dividing both sides of equation 4 by C and substituting σ = F/A into the formula, the following equation is obtained: (13) where z = C2/C.

When the elements with differential thickness are connected in series, force F acting on this system brings about variable local stresses. Denoting the cumulative distribution function of the cross-section field of the element with ϕ(A), the probability density of the occurrence of an element with cross-section field A or linear density, in the case of tenacity analysis, is: (14)
Thus, dϕ(A) = φ(A)dA.
Multiplying both sides of equation 13 by φ(A)dA results in: (15)
If the sample-loading force F is lower, the limits of elastic strains are reached; at this point x22 = 0, and equation 15 assumes the following form: (16)
Integrating this equation bilaterally within the limits (A1 ≤ A ≤ A2), where A1 and A2 are the minimal and maximal thicknesses of the element, respectively, one can obtain: (17)
Denoting the harmonic mean of the element thickness with Ah: (18) we obtain: (19)

Finally, when the tensile force does not exceed the elastic limit in any element, the relationship between elongation and the load remains linear; only the value of specific rigidity equal to the product CAh changes. Ifthe limiting value of linear strains is exceeded anywhere, both the expressions describing the linear and non-linear strains will appear on the right side of equation 15. Thus, we can bilaterally integrate equation 15 within the limits A1 ≤ A ≤ A2 to obtain: (20)

Further considerations require us to accept an approximate function of thickness or linear density distribution inside the sample section under tension. Auniform (rectangular) distribution was assumed as the first approximation. In such a case, the probability density function will assume the following form: (21) and value Ah can be determined by: (22)
By transferring the terms containing F to the left side of the equation, we obtain: (23)

In the case of the tenacity analysis for the uniform distribution, the values of maximal linear density A2 and minimal linear density A1 can be calculated from the formulae: A1=A¯-σ3 and A2=A¯+σ3, assuming that the mean value and the standard deviation are known.

sec.title: Solution of the rheological model on the basis of numerical methods
sec.p: The next means of calculating the response values of therheological model is the use of numerical methods.32,33 These methods allow us to analyse the response sensitivity of the model to the action of its particular elements in a simple way. The numerical methods also allow us to omit the labour required to determine the equation of state analytically. To obtain a diagram of model responses for the proposed model containing an inertial element, we assume the following: in the first stage, the state of stresses in particular model branches under condition that T2 ≥ σ2 will be analysed, while in the second stage T2 < σ2. To solve such a system, Runge-Kutt's method was used. The strain x22 as a function of time, and after conversion, assumes the form: (24)
Equation 24 was converted to obtain: (25) (26)

The converted equations were recorded in the form of 2 × 1 column vectors: (27) where dx22dt=x221was assumed as the first element and d2x22dt2=-η2mx221-C2mx220+C2mut1-T2m was assumed to be the second element.
The value of t1 is the moment at which the viscous element strain begins and is described by x22; x220 is a primitive function of x221.

The performed calculations give the strain x22, andthe rate, as x22 increases as a function of time. Next, thevalue of x22 is substituted into equation 4 to describe the model to calculate the strain values. The final stage combines both parts of the diagram and compares itwith the experimental diagram.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
The verification of the rheological model was carried out using monofilaments made from poly(ethylene terephthalate) by ‘Stilon’. According to the manufacturer, the monofilaments with a linear density of 272.4 tex were characterized by a tenacity of 36.9 cN/tex. Their maximal breaking force was 100.4 N, and the elongation under the maximal force was equal to 36.1%. These filaments were used in further tests and as standard samples to calculate the rheological model element coefficients. Considering the fact that the aim of this study is to assess whether it is possible to take into account linear density irregularity in the polyester monofilaments in the modelling, test samples were chemically treated to obtain considerable mass irregularity along the section length tested, with no changes in the supermolecular structure. The test material was modified by monofilament saponification of the top layer under the influence of a sodium base. The saponification process was performed at the boiling point of 8M NaOH solution for different lengths of time (0.5 to 1.5 h), which caused the diameters to change in the modified monofilaments. The sample characteristics subjected to particular chemical treatments are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Characteristics of saponification conditions
Sample symbol Treatment
Raw material Bath composition Temperature Treatment time
PET 1 Polyester monofilament Water 90°C 0.5 h
PET 2 Polyester monofilament 8 M NaOH 90°C 0.5 h
PET 3 Polyester monofilament Water 90°C 1 h
PET 4 Polyester monofilament 8 M NaOH 90°C 1 h
PET 5 Polyester monofilament Water 90°C 1.5 h
PET 6 Polyester monofilament 8 M NaOH 90°C 1.5 h
PET 7 Polyester monofilament No treatment

The linear density assessment after saponification under heterogeneous access of sodium hydroxide to the monofilament surface was performed with the following samples: PET 2, which represents a monofilament saponified for 0.5 h; PET 4, which was saponified for 1 h; and PET 6, which was saponified for 1.5 h. The linear density was tested by the gravimetric method on sections with lengths, 500 mm and 10 mm. The number of analyses in the 10-mm sections was 60, and in the long sections (500 mm), it was 10 for each variant. Below mean linear densities of the monofilament tested for particular modification times, including scatter indices, are given. For the standard samples subjected to heating in water at a temperature of 90°C, no heating time effect on the linear density and its variation coefficient was found. Therefore, sample PET 1 was accepted as the standard sample for the measurement of linear density. Test results are listed in Tables 2 and 3. The linear density of monofilaments was determined using weight balance of accuracy equal to 0.1 mg. Table 2.
Linear density of monofilaments measured on 500 mm sections
Saponification time (sample symbol)
Standard sample PET 1 0.5 h (PET 2) 1 h (PET 4) 1.5 h (PET 6)
Mean value, tex 272.1 264.41 243.1 214.03
Standard deviation 1.19 1.49 1.97 2.74
Coefficient of variation, % 0.43 0.56 0.81 1.28
Table 3.
Linear density of monofilament measured on 10 mm sections
Saponification time (sample symbol)
Standard sample PET 1 0.5 h (PET 2) 1 h (PET 4) 1.5 h (PET 6)
Mean value, tex 272.1 264.87 243.49 214.24
Standard deviation 2.04 4.05 9.04 16.73
Coefficient of variation, % 0.75 1.53 3.71 7.81
Minimal value of linear density calculated on the basis of uniform distribution A1, tex 270.8 257.85 227.83 185.26
Maximal value of linear density calculated on the basis of uniform distribution A2, tex 273.39 271.82 259.15 243.22

It was found that the prolonged saponification process resulted in monofilaments with a considerably decreased linear density. The saponification process performed for 0.5 h brought about a drop in the linear density of monofilaments by 2.6%, in relation to the linear density of monofilaments heated in water. Prolonging the saponification time up to 1 h caused a drop in linear density from 272.1 tex to 243.5 tex (a 10% decrease in relation to the standard sample). Further prolonging the treatment with sodium hydroxide brought about a drop in the linear density by more than 20%. It was also found that the linear density irregularity after saponification increased as indicated by the linear density variation coefficient. This phenomenon is particularly easy to observe in the short section case (10 mm), where the linear density variation coefficient increased from 0.75% (sample heated in water) to 7.8% for the sample saponified for 1.5 h. In Figure 2 the SEM images of investigated samples are presented. Figure 2.
SEM images of investigated monofilaments subjected to the saponification. PET 1, polyester monofilament; bath composition, water 90°C 0.5 h. PET 2, polyester monofilament; bath composition, 8 M NaOH 90°C 0.5 h. PET 4, polyester monofilament, bath composition, 8 M NaOH 90°C 1 h. PET 6, polyester monofilament, bath composition, 8 M NaOH 90°C 1.5 h.

In order to assess the effect of the chemical treatment performed on the filament supermolecular structure, the crystallinity degree and crystallite size were measured by the wide-angle scattering of x-rays (WAXS) method. The effect of the alkaline treatment on molecular structure was analysed on all the samples listed in Table 1. Moreover, the changes in the supermolecular structure of the saponified samples that were subjected to tensile forces were analysed. The samples subjected to tensile tests are denoted with index ‘z’. The test results are listed in Table 4. Based on the RTG tests, there were no significant changes in the supermolecular structure of the monofilaments subjected to the chemical treatment or tensile process. Table 4.
Results of WAXS measurements
Treatment time, h Sample Crystallinity degree, % Crystallite size D(101), Å Crystallite size D(110), Å Crystallite size D(100), Å Bragg distance d (101), Å Bragg distance d (110), Å Bragg distance d (100), Å
0.5 PET 1 57 55 47 38 5.0 4.0 3.5
PET 2 51 56 46 37 5.1 3.9 3.5
PET 2 z 54 50 46 36 5.1 4.0 3.5
1 PET 3 51 55 46 37 5.0 4.0 3.5
PET 4 59 54 46 40 5.1 3.9 3.5
PET 4 z 58 51 43 36 5.1 4.0 3.5
1.5 PET 5 55 55 46 38 5.0 4.0 3.5
PET 6 59 50 45 38 5.1 4.0 3.5
PET 6 z 56 45 41 34 5.1 4.0 3.5
0 PET 7 53 53 47 40 5.1 4.0 3.5

The examinations of the stress-strain curve of monofilaments were carried out in two stages using Instron tester 4200. First, a simple unidirectional tension was performed using three velocities: 50, 100 and 150 mm/min. In addition, three distances between clamps were used: 50, 100 and 150 mm. The tensile tests were performed on the monofilaments with decreased linear densities due to their saponification, as described in Table 1 and denoted with symbols PET 2, PET 4 and PET 6. In the second stage, stress relaxation tests were carried out to determine the coefficients of the equation describing the model proposed in this study. Therefore, the relaxation assessment was performed exclusively on the samples with homogeneous linear densities, which were heated in water; they are denoted in Table 1 by PET 1, PET 3 and PET 5. The monofilament tension was increased up to the assumed force, equal to 40 N, at rates of 50, 100 and 150 mm/min, and with selected distances between clamps: 50, 100 and 150 mm. The relaxation time was 300 s. The data concerning the tension process and the relaxation of homogeneous samples were used to determine the coefficients of the rheological model equation. The calculated coefficients were then used to calculate the theoretical stress-strain curve for irregular samples according to equation 23. In these calculations, three treatment times were taken into account: 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 h in an 8 M NaOH solution.

sec.title: Method for the determination of model coefficients
sec.p: The model coefficient determination was performed by analysing the physical phenomena that take place in both branches of the model considered in the successive tension phases of the tested monofilament sample. The calculation of spring specific rigidity was performed for the simplified model, assuming that, in the initial tension period, the stresses appearing in the sample are lower than the limiting value. The remaining coefficients were calculated for the complete model assuming that the stress exceeded the limiting value and that both visco-elastic and plastic strains existed.

For the case when C2x ≤ T2, the model was reduced to the form shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Simplified rheological model for C2x ≤ T2.

In order to determine the total specific rigidity of the model C = C1 + C2, the elasticity limit was determined by means of the diagram of changes in the ratio of force increment to elongation increment: ΔF/Δx. This diagram is shown in Figure 4. The specific rigidity limit point was located where the value of ΔF/Δx is rapidly changed. This place is denoted with letter A. Next, the straight line inclination angle to the initial part of the stress-strain curve was determined to be the regression equation on the basis of selected measurement points. Figure 4.
Diagram of ΔF/Δx for the determination of elasticity limits.

To evaluate the specific rigidity of particular springs, C1 and C2, the rheological model was simplified to the form shown in Figure 5, which illustrates the first actuating moment of Saint-Venant's element. Figure 5.
Simplified rheological model for actuating moment of Saint-Venant's element.

Analysing part of the diagram shown in Figure 4 further, point B was determined. Point B is fairly characteristic and is located where the stress-strain curveinclination angle changes. The diagram of ΔF/Δx passes from a rapid drop in increments to a stabilized value. Point B is connected with the object strain transition from elastic to plastic and visco-elastic strains. As soon as the mechanical frictional element begins itsmovement, one can evaluate the specific rigidity C1. This value can be evaluated by setting a regression line using the experimental points located near point B.

The next stage evaluated T2 by increasing the sample tension towards zone B. Once the assumed load σm was reached, the tension was stopped and the sample was subjected to relaxation. After relaxation, T2 was evaluated. From the model structure, it is known that the stress in branch II can be determined using equation 28. (28)
For the relaxation process, we assume that d 2x22dt⇒0. As a result of the relaxation, this process will stop when T2 = σ2. Thus, we assumed that: (29)

The value of xm is defined as the moment at which the tension is terminated. These relationships are illustrated in Figure 6, where σ1 = C1 · x Figure 6.
Schematic diagram for the evaluation of T2.

In the next stage, the constant η2, corresponding to specific viscosity, was determined. For tension above the elasticity limit, the model was reduced in mass to the form shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Rheological model reduced in mass.
For this simplified model, the following equation was deduced: (30)
Then, the specific viscosity, η2, was evaluated by substituting successive specific viscosity values that satisfy equation 30 at the analysed measurement point. (31)

Based on equation 31, the specific viscosity values for successive times t1 were obtained and shown in the diagram in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Specific viscosity values as a function of time.

The mass used in the model was evaluated based onthe determined coefficients and the equation describing the strain x22. Finding the mass allowed us to calculate the value of Δ such that equation x22 is equal to zero. This value was evaluated separately for each set of coefficients.

sec.title: Computational algorithm
sec.p:
The computational algorithm was prepared in the MathCad program. The use of this medium made it possible to simply and visibly control both the calculation process and the results at particular computational stages, while the simplified procedures of data combination and visualization allowed us to clearly present the calculation results. This algorithm takes into account model elements and the moment of transition from elastic to visco-elastic strains. Particular stages of the algorithm correspond to those of the model responses analytical calculation. The calculation process starts with the introduction of model coefficients with theexperimental data that contain the experimental stress-strain curve of the test object (Figure 9). The input data also include the values of the maximal and minimal linear densities and tension rate. Based on the introduced data, the program begins the computational procedures. First, the time to tension termination is determined by searching the last measurement point of the experimental data. Next, the program sets the point in the stress-strain curve that corresponds to the moment when the mechanical frictional element starts to move (point of exceeding the limiting strains). In the next phase, the program begins to calculate the fragment of the stress-strain curve that corresponds to elastic strains. These values are evaluated from the initial moment, t = 0, to the point where the limiting stress is exceeded and the mechanical frictional element starts. These calculations are performed at the assumed step of 0.001 s. The program presents the results in the form of diagrams of stress versus time and stores them in the form of a result matrix. Once the analysis of the first part of the stress-strain curve is terminated, the program begins to calculate the piston strain when the value of the mechanical frictional element limiting stress is exceeded. To solve the system of differential equations describing this strain, the program uses Runge-Kutt's method. The calculations made with the boundary conditions indicate that the strain and its first derivative are equal to zero at the moment the visco-elastic strains begin. The results are presented in the form of diagrams of stress versus time and stored as a result matrix. Based on the results, the program calculates the stress for the whole model. Next, taking into account the conditions concerning the thickness irregularities of the object tested, the program calculates the force for parts I and II of the model. The results are presented in the form of diagrams containing the curves obtained from theoretical computation and the experimental curves and their 95% confidence limits. Figure 9.
Calculation process used in the computational algorithm.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Based on the performed simulation, one can verify the accuracy of the model operation with the analytically determined values of its coefficients by comparing the theoretical stress-strain curve run with the run of the experimental stress-strain curve determined for irregular polyester monofilaments.

sec.title: Coefficients of the rheological equation for regular monofilaments
sec.p:
The coefficients were calculated based on uniform polyester monofilament tension data with a given linear density. The tension was carried out at three rates of beam travel, 50, 100 and 150 mm/min, and for three distances between clamps: 50, 100 and 150 mm. The model coefficients calculated for all tension variants are listed in Tables 5–7. Table 5.
Coefficients of the model for monofilaments subjected to tension with the distance between clamps equal to 50 mm
Tension rate, 50 mm/min Tension rate, 100 mm/min Tension rate, 150 mm/min
ϕ 272.00 272.00 272.0
C1 9.50 10.00 9.80
C2 89.66 81.93 78.28
η2 52.27 29.01 19.83
T2 0.04 0.04 0.03
m 7.62 2.57 1.26
Table 6.
Coefficients of the model for monofilaments subjected to tension with the distance between clamps equal to 100 mm
Tension rate, 50 mm/min Tension rate, 100 mm/min Tension rate, 150 mm/min
ϕ 272.00 272.00 272.00
C1 5.60 5.70 6.00
C2 50.12 44.77 49.71
η2 51.44 26.04 18.10
T2 0.04 0.03 0.03
m 13.20 3.79 1.65
Table 7.
Coefficients of the model for monofilaments subjected to tension with the distance between clamps equal to 150 mm
Tension rate, 50 mm/min Tension rate, 100 mm/min Tension rate, 150 mm/min
ϕ 272.00 272.00 272.00
C1 4.30 4.40 4.40
C2 33.00 35.00 32.00
η2 50.61 26.65 17.25
T2 0.03 0.03 0.03
m 19.41 5.07 2.32
Symbols given in Tables 5–7 have the following meaning:
ϕ – nominal linear density, tex,
C1 – specific rigidity if spring I, Ntex·m,
C2 – specific rigidity of spring II, Ntex·m,
η2 – specific viscosity of Newton's dumper, N·stex·m,
T2 – resistance of mechanical frictional element, Ntex,
m – mass of inertial element, kg.

From the model coefficients calculated based on the regular polyester monofilament stress-strain curves, it follows that some of the coefficients are dependent on the tension conditions, including the specific viscosity η2, whose value decreases as the tension rate decreases. It seems that this phenomenon results from the fact that the local temperature increases as the tension rate increases, causing the specific viscosity to decrease. The model coefficients that depend on the distance between clamps are the spring specific rigidities denoted as C1 and C2. As the distance between clamps increases, the spring specific rigidity drops, which results from thehigher number of defects in samples with increasing section length. For longer distances between clamps, theprobability of a defect in the structure increases. Moreover, it was found that, depending on the homogeneous monofilament tension conditions, the coefficient of mass changes. Nevertheless, these changes are difficult to define. For the mechanical frictional element limiting stress, its value does not depend on the tension rate or the distance between clamps.

Based on the coefficients listed in Tables 5–7, the irregular monofilament stress-strain curves were calculated with an assumed uniform distribution of linear densities. The course of theoretical irregular monofilaments stress-strain curves was determined for various tension conditions: three tension rates (50, 100 and 150 mm/min) and three distances between clamps (50, 100 and 150 mm). The calculated theoretical curves were presented in the form of diagrams. Figure 10 shows an example of such a diagram calculated with a model monofilament (a modified monofilament with a linear density of 264 tex) with a tension rate of 50 mm/min and a distance between clamps of 50 mm. Figure 10.
Diagram of the tension force calculated on the basis of the model monofilament with a tension rate of 50 mm/min and a distance between clamps of 50 mm; modified monofilament of 264 tex.

The presented diagram illustrates the course of the theoretical curve in relation to the experimental curve obtained by tensioning the irregular polyester monofilaments under the conditions of the experiment. Moreover, this diagram shows the curves that correspond to the 95% confidence limit. The line specified as ‘solid’ illustrates the course of the stress-strain curve of regular monofilaments with a nominal linear density of 272 tex, whose coefficients were introduced in the rheological model.

The run of both the theoretical and experimental curves indicates that the proposed rheological model allowed us to calculate the theoretical curve and to reliably anticipate the behaviour of irregular monofilaments under tension. The curve equation was evaluated based on the coefficients resulting from the regular monofilaments' tension and the irregular monofilaments' linear density spread coefficients. The convergence of the theoretical and experimental curves for particular tension variants was confirmed by the calculated values of the curvilinear correlation coefficient listed in Table 8. Table 8.
Coefficients of the curvilinear correlation between the theoretical and experimental curves determined for the variants tested
Linear density Coefficients of the curvilinear correlation obtained for tests conducted under various conditions
tex 50 mm, 50 mm/min 50 mm, 100 mm/min 50 mm, 150 mm/min
264 0.99 0.99 0.99
243 0.99 0.99 0.98
214 0.97 0.99 0.97
tex 100 mm, 50 mm/min 100 mm, 100 mm/min 100 mm, 150 mm/min
264 0.99 0.99 0.99
243 0.99 0.98 0.99
214 0.96 0.96 0.98
tex 150 mm, 50 mm/min 150 mm, 100 mm/min 150 mm, 150 mm/min
264 0.99 0.99 0.99
243 0.99 0.99 0.99
214 0.99 0.99 0.98
In all the tested cases, the curvilinear correlation coefficient exceeded 0.95, and it was higher than 0.99 for the majority of the analysed curves.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The calculations and comparison of the theoretical and experimental curves allowed us to draw the following conclusions. First, the developed model, consisting of a Hooke's spring with specific rigidity C1 and a Hooke's spring with specific rigidity C2 connected in series with a frictional element with a constant resistance T2 and with a piston with mass m that displaces a liquid with specific viscosity η2, has fulfilled the aims of this study; it describes the function of the polyester monofilaments monotonic tension after exceeding the elasticity limit and takes into account the phenomena resulting from the linear density distribution irregularity in the tested object. Furthermore, the curvilinear correlation coefficient between the theoretical curve and the related actual curve, which in the majority of the tested cases exceeded 0.99, indicates that the proposed model and its solution allow us to anticipate the course of monotonic tension of real objects. In addition, a relationship has been found between the coefficients of the rheological equation of state and the assumed tension conditions of the tested object. They include spring rigidities C1 and C2, specific viscosity η2 and the mass of dumper. The frictional element with resistance T2 is independent of the tension conditions. In the case of the specific viscosity coefficient η2, its value decreases as the tension rate increases. This relation indicates that the PET monofilaments behave like non-Newtonian fluids for which dynamic viscosity is a function of speed of deformation. According to the literature,34 reduction of viscosity for non-Newtonian fluids results from the increase of ordering of molecules while the speed of deformation raises. The coefficients C1 and C2, which reflect the spring rigidities, are inversely proportional to the distance between clamps. This dependence is due to the increase in the number of structure defects when a section with a greater length is tensioned. Finally, the inertial element added to the model changes its value, but it is impossible to explicitly define the character of these changes and their dependence on the tension conditions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Ministry of Science and Higher Education, Poland (grant number 3 T08E 081 28).
